logTitle: IELTS Reading Log: Roman shipbuilding and navigation

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Shipbuilding today is based on science and ships are built using computers and sophisticated tools.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Advanced and complex instruments or devices

phase3Production.content: Modern surgeons use sophisticated tools to perform minimally invasive operations.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Shipbuilding in ancient Rome, however, was more of an art relying on estimation, inherited techniques and personal experience.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To depend on a rough calculation or judgment rather than precise measurement

phase3Production.content: Without a map, we were relying on estimation to find our way back.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...relying on estimation, inherited techniques and personal experience.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Methods or skills passed down from previous generations
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các kỹ thuật được kế thừa

phase3Production.content: The family business succeeded by using inherited techniques combined with modern technology.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The Romans were not traditionally sailors but mostly land-based people...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: People who live and work on land, as opposed to at sea

phase3Production.content: The transition from being a land-based people to a naval power was crucial for their empire.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: There are a few surviving written documents that give descriptions and representations of ancient Roman ships...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Historical texts that still exist today
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các tài liệu viết còn sót lại

phase3Production.content: From the few surviving written documents, we can learn about their legal system.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Excavated vessels also provide some clues about ancient shipbuilding techniques.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Ships that have been uncovered by digging in the ground or seabed
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Các con tàu được khai quật

phase3Production.content: The museum displays several excavated vessels from the Viking age.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...ancient Roman shipbuilders built the outer hull first, then proceeded with the frame and the rest of the ship.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The main body or exterior shell of a ship

phase3Production.content: The ship's outer hull was damaged in the collision.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Planks used to build the outer hull were initially sewn together.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: At first, they were stitched together
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Ban đầu được khâu lại với nhau

phase3Production.content: The pieces of the leather bag were initially sewn together by hand.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Starting from the 6th century BCE, they fixed using a method called mortise and tenon...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A type of joint, used in woodworking, where a projection (tenon) on one piece of wood is inserted into a hole (mortise) in another

phase3Production.content: Traditional furniture is often built using strong mortise and tenon joints.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: This method was more systematic and dramatically shortened ship construction times.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: More methodical, organized, and based on a clear plan

phase3Production.content: We need a more systematic approach to solving this problem.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and dramatically shortened ship construction times.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To make something much shorter in duration

phase3Production.content: The new highway has dramatically shortened my commute to work.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...whose size and technology were unequalled until the 16th century CE.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Better or greater than anyone or anything else up to a certain point in time
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Không gì sánh bằng cho đến khi

phase3Production.content: His skill as a painter was unequalled until the rise of the Renaissance masters.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Warships were built to be lightweight and very speedy.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Having little weight and capable of moving very quickly

phase3Production.content: The new racing bike is designed to be lightweight and very speedy.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: They had to be able to sail near the coast, which is why they had no ballast or excess load...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Không có 'vật dằn' (ballast) 'hoặc' (or) 'tải trọng thừa' (excess load)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Without heavy material placed in a ship to provide stability or any extra weight beyond what is necessary
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Không có vật dằn hoặc tải trọng thừa

phase3Production.content: To increase its speed, the racing yacht carried no ballast or excess load.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...following naval battles.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Combat fought at sea between warships

phase3Production.content: The Battle of Trafalgar is one of the most famous naval battles in history.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: They had a bronze battering ram, which was used to pierce the timber hulls...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Một 'mũi nhọn công phá' (battering ram) 'bằng đồng' (bronze)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A heavy beam, tipped with bronze, used in ancient warfare to breach fortifications or the sides of ships
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Mũi nhọn công phá bằng đồng

phase3Production.content: The warship was equipped with a bronze battering ram to sink enemy vessels.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...which was used to pierce the timber hulls or break the oars of enemy vessels.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To make a hole through the wooden main body of a ship
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Đâm thủng thân tàu bằng gỗ

phase3Production.content: The sharp rock was able to pierce the timber hull of the small boat.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Eventually, Rome’s navy became the largest and most powerful in the Mediterranean, and the Romans had control over what they therefore called Mare Nostrum...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To have the power to influence or direct people's behavior or the course of events

phase3Production.content: The manager had control over the entire department.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The ‘trireme’ was the dominant warship from the 7th to 4th century BCE.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The most common, powerful, or influential type of military ship

phase3Production.content: For centuries, the galleon was the dominant warship of the Spanish navy.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: It is worth noting that contrary to popular perception, rowers were not slaves but mostly Roman citizens...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: In opposition to what is generally believed or understood
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Trái với nhận thức phổ biến

phase3Production.content: Contrary to popular perception, bats are not blind.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...mostly Roman citizens enrolled in the military.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To officially join the armed forces

phase3Production.content: He enrolled in the military right after finishing high school.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The trireme was superseded by larger ships with even more rowers.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be replaced by something newer, more modern, or more effective

phase3Production.content: The horse-drawn carriage was superseded by the automobile.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Merchant ships were built to transport lots of cargo over long distances...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To carry a large quantity of goods by ship, aircraft, or motor vehicle

phase3Production.content: Large container ships are used to transport lots of cargo across oceans.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...over long distances and at a reasonable cost.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: For a price that is fair and not too expensive

phase3Production.content: You can get a good meal at a reasonable cost in the university cafeteria.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and a solid interior for added stability.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: For extra firmness and steadiness

phase3Production.content: The boat has a wide base for added stability in rough water.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...but coordinating the hundreds of rowers in both types of ship was not an easy task.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Organizing the large number of people who row a boat so they work together effectively
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Điều phối hàng trăm tay chèo

phase3Production.content: Coordinating the hundreds of volunteers for the event was a huge challenge.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...was not an easy task.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Không phải là 'một nhiệm vụ' (a task) 'dễ dàng' (easy)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A difficult job or piece of work
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Không phải là một nhiệm vụ dễ dàng

phase3Production.content: Raising children is not an easy task.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The cargo on merchant ships included raw materials (e.g. iron bars, copper, marble and granite)...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The basic material from which a product is made

phase3Production.content: The country is rich in raw materials like oil and timber.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: During the Empire, Rome was a huge city by ancient standards of about one million inhabitants.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: When judged in comparison with things from ancient times

phase3Production.content: The library was enormous by ancient standards.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...a huge city by ancient standards of about one million inhabitants.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A person or animal that lives in or occupies a place

phase3Production.content: The city has over five million inhabitants.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...through the gigantic port of Ostia situated at the mouth of the Tiber River.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: An extremely large town or city with a harbour where ships load and unload

phase3Production.content: Singapore has a gigantic port that handles millions of containers each year.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Large merchant ships would approach the destination port and, just like today, be intercepted by a number of towboats that would drag them to the quay.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Bị 'chặn lại/tiếp cận' (intercepted by) bởi 'tàu kéo' (towboats)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be stopped and guided on the way to a destination by tugboats
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Bị tàu kéo chặn lại/tiếp cận

phase3Production.content: The large oil tanker was intercepted by several towboats to guide it safely into the harbour.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...towboats that would drag them to the quay.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To pull them with force to the stone or metal platform lying alongside or projecting into water for loading and unloading ships

phase3Production.content: The powerful tugboat began to drag the massive container ship to the quay.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The time of travel along the many sailing routes could vary widely.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To differ greatly; to be very different in size, amount, or nature

phase3Production.content: Opinions on the new policy vary widely among the public.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...but on experience, local knowledge and observation of natural phenomena.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Facts or situations that are observed to exist or happen, especially ones whose cause or explanation is in question, which are not man-made

phase3Production.content: The aurora borealis is one of the most beautiful natural phenomena.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: In conditions of good visibility, seamen in the Mediterranean often had the mainland or islands in sight...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Conditions in which it is possible to see clearly over long distances

phase3Production.content: Pilots require conditions of good visibility to land the plane safely.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...often had the mainland or islands in sight, which greatly facilitated navigation.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Visible; able to be seen

phase3Production.content: After many days at sea, land was finally in sight.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...which greatly facilitated navigation.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Tạo điều kiện thuận lợi' (facilitated) 'rất nhiều' (greatly) 'cho việc định vị' (navigation)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To make the process of finding a route much easier
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Tạo điều kiện thuận lợi rất nhiều cho việc định vị

phase3Production.content: The invention of the compass greatly facilitated navigation for sailors.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: They sailed by noting their position relative to a succession of recognisable landmarks.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Một 'chuỗi' (succession of) 'các địa danh' (landmarks) 'dễ nhận biết' (recognisable)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A series of features of a landscape that are easily seen and identified from a distance
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Một chuỗi các địa danh dễ nhận biết

phase3Production.content: We navigated through the city by following a succession of recognisable landmarks.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Roman mariners estimated directions from the pole star or, with less accuracy, from the Sun at noon.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A star, especially Polaris, that is located in the celestial sphere close to one of the celestial poles

phase3Production.content: Sailors have used the pole star for navigation for centuries.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...or, with less accuracy, from the Sun at noon.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Not as precisely or correctly
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Với độ chính xác thấp hơn

phase3Production.content: The old map showed the river's course with less accuracy than modern GPS.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Overall, shipping in ancient Roman times resembled shipping today with large vessels regularly crossing the seas...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Was similar to the transport of goods by sea
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Giống với ngành vận tải biển

phase3Production.content: In many ways, ancient trade resembled the global shipping networks we have now.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...with large vessels regularly crossing the seas and bringing supplies from their Empire.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Frequently travelling over the oceans

phase3Production.content: Container ships are regularly crossing the seas to deliver goods worldwide.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Warships used both wind (sails) and human power (oarsmen) and were therefore very fast.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A person who rows a boat, especially as a member of a crew

phase3Production.content: A team of strong oarsmen powered the ancient galley through the water.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: The rowers at the bottom had the most uncomfortable position as they were under the other rowers...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The least pleasant or physically easy place to be

phase3Production.content: Sitting in the middle seat on a long flight is the most uncomfortable position.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and were exposed to the water entering through the oar-holes.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be in a situation where one is not protected from water

phase3Production.content: The sailors on deck were constantly exposed to the water from the crashing waves.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...water entering through the oar-holes.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Openings in the side of a boat through which the oars are passed for rowing

phase3Production.content: Water splashed in through the oar-holes as they rowed.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...rowers were not slaves but mostly Roman citizens enrolled in the military.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: People who were legally recognized as members of the ancient Roman state, with associated rights and responsibilities

phase3Production.content: Only Roman citizens were allowed to vote in the elections.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Their V-shaped hull was deep underwater, meaning that they could not sail too close to the coast.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The main body of a ship that is shaped like the letter V

phase3Production.content: Modern speedboats often have a V-shaped hull to cut through the water efficiently.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: They usually had two huge side rudders located off the stern...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Steering devices located on the sides of a boat, typically near the back

phase3Production.content: Ancient ships often used large side rudders for steering instead of a single rudder at the stern.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...located off the stern and controlled by a small tiller bar...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The rearmost part of a ship or boat

phase3Production.content: The ship's name was painted on the stern.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...controlled by a small tiller bar connected to a system of cables.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A lever used to turn a rudder and steer a boat

phase3Production.content: The sailor used the tiller bar to change the boat's direction.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: They had from one to three masts with large square sails...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A tall upright post on a boat or ship, supporting the sails

phase3Production.content: The tall ship had three masts and many sails.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and a small triangular sail at the bow.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The forward part of the hull of a ship or boat

phase3Production.content: The waves crashed against the bow of the ship.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...raw materials (e.g. iron bars, copper, marble and granite)...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Long, solid pieces of iron

phase3Production.content: The blacksmith forged the hot iron bars into a gate.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and agricultural products (e.g. grain from Egypt’s Nile valley).

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The fertile area of land along the Nile River in Egypt

phase3Production.content: Ancient Egyptian civilization flourished in the fertile Nile valley.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Large merchant ships would approach the destination port...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The port to which a ship is sailing

phase3Production.content: After a long voyage, the ship finally reached its destination port.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...seamen in the Mediterranean often had the mainland or islands in sight...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A person who works as a sailor, especially one below the rank of officer

phase3Production.content: The experienced seamen knew how to read the weather.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: When weather conditions were not good or where land was no longer visible, Roman mariners estimated directions...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: A sailor

phase3Production.content: Ancient mariners navigated by the stars.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: They also estimated directions relative to the wind and swell.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The movement of the air and the slow, regular movement of the sea in rolling waves that do not break

phase3Production.content: The small boat rocked gently in the wind and swell.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and often would lie crippled on the sea’s surface following naval battles.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Nằm 'hư hỏng nặng/tàn phế' (crippled) trên mặt biển

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Severely damaged or disabled
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Bị hư hỏng nặng, bị làm cho tàn phế

phase3Production.content: The ship was crippled by the storm and had to be towed to port.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...the largest and most powerful in the Mediterranean...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The sea connected to the Atlantic Ocean, surrounded by the Mediterranean Basin and almost completely enclosed by land

phase3Production.content: The Roman Empire controlled all the lands bordering the Mediterranean.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...from the Sun at noon.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Từ mặt trời 'vào buổi trưa' (at noon)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: At twelve o'clock in the middle of the day

phase3Production.content: The ship's captain took a reading from the sun at noon to determine their latitude.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...resembled shipping today with large vessels regularly crossing the seas...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Big ships or boats

phase3Production.content: The port is deep enough to accommodate large vessels.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...crossing the seas and bringing supplies from their Empire.

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Carrying necessary items such as food, equipment, and other essentials

noun.meaning: sự cung cấp, đồ tiếp tế

phase3Production.content: The army convoy was responsible for bringing supplies to the front line.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...who learned to build ships from the people that they conquered, namely the Greeks and the Egyptians.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Những người mà họ đã 'chinh phục' (conquered)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To overcome and take control of a place or people by use of military force

phase3Production.content: Alexander the Great conquered a vast empire stretching from Greece to India.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...built the outer hull first, then proceeded with the frame and the rest of the ship.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Sau đó 'tiếp tục với' (proceeded with) phần khung

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To begin or continue a course of action

phase3Production.content: After the introduction, the speaker proceeded with the main part of her presentation.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...Mediterranean shipbuilders shifted to another shipbuilding method...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Chuyển sang' (shifted to) một phương pháp khác

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To change from one position, state, or course of action to another

phase3Production.content: The company's focus has shifted from hardware to software in recent years.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...which consisted of building the frame first and then proceeding with the hull...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Phương pháp này 'bao gồm' (consisted of) việc xây dựng khung trước

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be composed or made up of

phase3Production.content: The committee consisted of five members.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: It is worth noting that contrary to popular perception, rowers were not slaves...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: 'Đáng chú ý là' (It is worth noting that)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: To be interesting or important enough to be mentioned

phase3Production.content: It is worth noting that the study had a very small sample size.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Unlike warships, their V-shaped hull was deep underwater...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: In contrast to; different from

phase3Production.content: Unlike his brother, he is very shy.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...and, just like today, be intercepted by a number of towboats...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: In the same way as happens in the present time

phase3Production.content: Just like today, ancient cities faced problems with overcrowding and sanitation.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: They sailed by noting their position relative to a succession of recognisable landmarks.

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Vị trí 'của họ' (their) 'so với/liên quan đến' (relative to)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: The location of something in comparison with the location of something else
phase2Annotation.translationVI: Vị trí tương đối so với

phase3Production.content: The value of the currency is determined by its position relative to the US dollar.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: ...where land was no longer visible...

phase1Inference.contextualGuessVI: Đất liền 'không còn' (no longer) 'nhìn thấy được' (visible)

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Not able to be seen anymore

phase3Production.content: As the ship sailed away from the shore, the coastline was no longer visible.

lexicalItems.sourceContext: Overall, shipping in ancient Roman times resembled shipping today...

phase2Annotation.definitionEN: Taking everything into account; in general

phase3Production.content: There were a few minor problems, but overall, the event was a great success.
